note.body:
I'm trying to get a development setup running in Ubuntu 18.04 (Bionic Beaver). So far I've compiled this list:

* meson
* ninja-build
* rustc
* cargo
* libglib2.0-dev
* cmake
* libdbus-1-dev
* libcairo2-dev
* libatk1.0-dev
* libgstreamer1.0-dev
* libpango1.0-dev
* libgdk-pixbuf2.0-dev
* libgstreamer-plugins-base1.0-dev
* libgtk-3-dev
* libgtksourceview-3.0-dev
* libgstreamer-plugins-base1.0-dev
* libgstreamer-plugins-good1.0-dev
* libgstreamer-plugins-bad1.0-dev

Now I'm stuck on another dependency, which I'm not sure how to resolve. The `libgspell-1-dev` package is only version `1.6.1-1`, where `>= 1.8` is required. So I still need to figure that one out.

##### Update
Opening the project in Gnome Builder, the missing gspell library is checked out automatically. So perhaps the main recommendation is to just use Gnome Builder!

##### Update 2
When trying to run the application from GNOME Builder, it fails, because of the lack of root privileges. So while it seems to resolve the rust package for gspell, it cannot install properly. I've given up for now.

GDK does not respect XDG_SESSION_TYPE - causing issues
GDK does not respect XDG_SESSION_TYPE - causing issues

note.body:
The best I could find so far is this:
https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/pam_systemd.html#%24XDG_SESSION_TYPE

Note that for example GDM knows about that variable and sets it. Even the mentioned gnome-session-check-accelerated reads this variable when trying to determine if it is running in X11 or in Wayland.

events.target_title: GDK does not respect XDG_SESSION_TYPE - causing issues

note.body:
I would say `XDG_SESSION_TYPE` is not a random variable, it is **the** variable to look at.

But even if you don't accept using `XDG_SESSION_TYPE`, some other solution is still needed since this is a real bug. If you start a Wayland session, you can no longer open any GDK applications in any X11 session - they will all appear in the Wayland session instead. That is clearly incorrect behavior.

events.target_title: GDK does not respect XDG_SESSION_TYPE - causing issues
GDK does not respect XDG_SESSION_TYPE - causing issues

note.body:
> But who decided it, and why hasn't anybody bothered to tell the toolkit maintainers before people started to rely on it? Where or when was it discussed, and were there toolkit developers available?

I tried to dig into history and so far it seems that it was introduced in systemd by Lennart Poettering without any prior discussion. I am going to ask on xdg mailing list...

Implementation-wise, my understanding is that `XDG_SESSION_TYPE` should be a hint on which backend should be tried first. So in situations when there are multiple backends available and they both could succeed, you know which one to try first.

> If you need a particular backend, use GDK_BACKEND. I don't think any other variables are needed.

And Qt has QT_QPA_PLATFORM, SDL has SDL_VIDEODRIVER, etc.. But we can't expect every display manager to set every toolkit-specific variable.

From a user point of view I don't really care which backend is used. But when I click an application icon, I want the application window to appear in the same session where I clicked the icon. If it appears in some other one, that is a bug.

events.target_title: GDK does not respect XDG_SESSION_TYPE - causing issues

note.body: One alternative solution I can offer is to change the Wayland backend to call `wl_display_connect` only when the `WAYLAND_DISPLAY` variable is set. Because if it is not, it will default to "wayland-0" and potentially connect to an unrelated session.

events.target_title: GDK does not respect XDG_SESSION_TYPE - causing issues

note.body: It is not so unusual for people to run two sessions at the same time. For example you may want to have local Wayland session and remote Xvnc/Xrfb session. Real user got affected by this problem, link to downstream bug is in the initial description.

events.target_title: GTK application launched in Xorg session connects to a Wayland server instead

note.body:
> Maybe debug instances of compositors shouldn't use `wayland-0`.

Unfortunately the issue does not happen just with debug/nested compositors. The original bug describes the real-life issue: User was logged into a Wayland session locally (`wayland-0`) and also started Xvnc for a separate headless X session. But nothing appeared in the Xvnc though because all applications decided to display into the Wayland session.

events.target_title: GTK application launched in Xorg session connects to a Wayland server instead

note.body:
> I don't understand why using `XDG_SESSION_TYPE` is necessary. It also doesn't handle all use-cases. For instance: login from the TTY, start a Wayland compositor or X11. In this case `XDG_SESSION_TYPE` won't be set.

IMHO this use case can not be handled automatically. When the user starts Wayland compositor or X server manually, then the user also must manually tell the application in what *environment* it is running.

> Additionally, `XDG_SESSION_TYPE` is systemd-specific. Should compositors set it?

Not the compositors. Systemd-aware display managers set it.

> Instead, `WAYLAND_DISPLAY` can be used. It's hardcoded in libwayland, so it won't change.

The problem is that when the `WAYLAND_DISPLAY` is not set, libwayland will fallback to `wayland-0` and that may succeed if the same user happens to have a Wayland session on `wayland-0`.

events.target_title: crash when drmModeGetResources() fails

note.body:
I think the problem here is that `meta_gpu_kms_new` calls `drmModeGetResources` and then doesn't check whether it succeeded before dereferencing the returned pointer. Note in the backtrace that `drm_resources` is 0x0.
```c
  /* Some GPUs might have no connectors, for example dedicated GPUs on PRIME (hybrid) laptops.
   * These GPUs cannot render anything on separate screens, and they are aggressively switched
   * off by the kernel.
   *
   * If we add these PRIME GPUs to the GPU list anyway, Mutter keeps awakening the secondary GPU,
   * and doing this causes a considerable stuttering. These GPUs are usually put to sleep again
   * after ~2s without a workload.
   *
   * For now, to avoid this situation, only create the MetaGpuKms when the GPU has any connectors.
   */
  drm_resources = drmModeGetResources (kms_fd);

  n_connectors = drm_resources->count_connectors; // <--- crash here
```

push_data.commit_title: gpu-kms: Don't crash if drmModeGetResources returns NULL

Thanks, I didn't realize you could do that. Seems to work.

I was going to say it might make sense to return `META_GPU_KMS_ERROR_NO_CONNECTORS` for these so they're handled the same as DRM devices that support modesetting but don't have connectors, but I guess the only real difference is `g_message` vs. `g_warning` in `meta_monitor_manager_kms_initable_init`.

events.target_title: bwraped thumbnailers cannot access X11/OpenGL anymore

note.body:
I'm actually running into the same problem. I've been working on [another thumbnailer for STL files](https://github.com/unlimitedbacon/stl-thumb), which uses OpenGL. Inside of the bwrap sandbox it cannot access the OpenGL backend.

Unfortunately X11 is needed in order to create a GL context. In addition, libGL needs access to the DRI components in order to use hardware acceleration. Flatpak knows how to handle all this. I think Gnome could just follow their example.

events.target_title: bwraped thumbnailers cannot access X11/OpenGL anymore

note.body:
>  as there's no reason they should need X11 or OpenGL support to generate the thumbnails

Uhm what? Are you saying that we should not be using OpenGL to render 3D models? If so, that's just stupid.

I understand the security concerns and I'm willing to work with Gnome to find a solution that opens the sandbox as little as possible. However I cannot do that if you dismiss our problems out of hand.

As @lhaond pointed out above, xvfb is a possible alternative to X11. There are also OpenGL extensions which allow for true headless rendering, however this is not supported on all hardware. The unfortunate truth is that OpenGL was designed to always have some kind of display output in the pipeline. Headless rendering was an afterthought.

Even with X11 out of the way, the sandbox still prevents us from using hardware acceleration. I experimented with using bwrap with @lhaond's options above. Although I was able to get an OpenGL context, it was with the Mesa software renderer instead of the hardware renderer for my Radeon GPU. I believe this is because the sandbox is preventing access to devices or libraries needed for using the GPU drivers. I'm not exactly sure what is required, though, and I also think that it varies from one GPU vendor/driver to another. This is why I suggested copying Flatpak's implementation earlier.

events.target_title: GDK does not respect XDG_SESSION_TYPE - causing issues

note.body:
XDG_SESSION_ID, XDG_SESSION_TYPE, XDG_SESSION_CLASS, XDG_SESSION_DESKTOP, XDG_SEAT, XDG_VTNR are all systemd inventions. I added them back when we introduced XDG_RUNTIME_DIR. I chose the prefix XDG_ because there were supposed to become defined in an fdo spec of some kind, but I never bothered to actually do that, I didn't want to have all those discussions... (For the XDG_RUNTIME_DIR stuff I did do the work, and it is part of xdg-basedir since a long time)

I think it would still make a lot of sense to write a formal fdo spec for them, if anyone cares (I am not volunteering). That said, they are documented within the systemd context and will be set on all sessions on all systemd systems:

https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/pam_systemd.html

Hence, they are definitely documented API already and have been for a long time, without any sort of API breakage or anything. The question is simply whether systemd is good enough as a standardizing body for you, or if you want something in fdo instead...

note.body:
@mitch  Absolutely. 
Been ranting about that since months ago! This has happened with each revision of the 2.10.X branch.
It won't work. I've even formatted my laptop, and made an extremely clean installation and it won't do anything at all. It keeps behaving like that.

I've asked on Facebook forums about this issue and many agrees with me. They too have this behavior. Some even has told me to "Just reset everything back, it won't take you longer than a minute"

Exceptionally slow drawing performance in GIMP 2.10.4 compared to 2.8.16
Exceptionally slow drawing performance in GIMP 2.10.4 compared to 2.8.16

note.body:
I use Windows 8

Mind if I ask, but with: "Drawing the rotated canvas boils down to a simple matrix on the output cairo_t."
Do you mean that gimp first renders the view-able part of the image, before rotating that to fit the UI, or do you mean that it renders each layer and rotates it before adding it to the output?

Since rotating of any kind will add extra processing time.
So the question is, and what I even postulated in the post above, is the following:

If rotating takes X processing time per pixel.
It takes Y processing time to add a pixel from one layer to the output buffer.
And we have N layers.

Then we can do 1 of two things.

One is to rotate each layer before we add it to the buffer. This means we will spend N * Y + N * X per pixel.

The other method is that we don't rotate each layer before adding it to the buffer, but instead rotate the whole buffer before outputting it to the screen. Then we will only spend N * Y + X per pixel.

And as long as we have more then 1 layer, the later process is always going to be faster. (And if we have 1 layer, then they are equal.)
(Not to mention, if GIMP in the future wants to add "effects layers" ie non destructive editing. Then we wouldn't need to worry about canvas rotation while doing that, since canvas rotation is handled post rendering.)

Though, one could and should make the case that we would need a bit of overlap outside the actual image that will be shown to the screen, as to make sure that our rotation doesn't screw up the edge of the screen area. Even though this is a question of only a few pixels, this will though be needed in both situation. So this extra will be added N times to the first method, but only 1 time to the later method, yet again proving that it has better performance. (We will still need to render the extra on all layers, but we don't need to rotate it if all canvas rotation is done post rendering.)

For these reasons I greatly hope that the GIMP development community hasn't taken the route of rotating each layer individually before adding them to the output buffer.

events.target_title: Exceptionally slow drawing performance in GIMP 2.10.4 compared to 2.8.16

note.body:
Having used GIMP 2.10.4 and "not minding" the large lack of performance, I have made a few observations:
1. Drawing works rather flawlessly in and of itself, so editing a layer and adding the line to it isn't a problem.
2. Undoing stuff (ctrl-z) is remarkably slow for some odd reason. (This is consistent, but layer size dependent.)
3. Most of the time the program stutters and sometimes even freezes for a few seconds (sometimes over a minute). "Fix" can be found near the end. (It though compromises the performance if one does more heavy stuff.)

This third point happens rather regardless of what one is doing, things that seems to trigger this stutter are:
Canvas rotation
Drawing
Erasing (seems worse then drawing)
Scaling and rotating layers

The problem seems fairly rare if one works at sub 2000 x 2000 pixels. (Though, my computer only has a total RAM bandwidth of about 17GB/s and "max canvas size" before running into consistent stutter is likely RAM bandwidth dependent. (I will check that and add more details later.))

What confuses me is that adding more layers doesn't seem to make the problem worse. A picture up in the 6000 x 7000 pixel area on my rig is consistently stuttering regardless if it has 1 layer or 100+ layers. While a 1000 x 1000 image only has a small stutter occasionally, and even here I haven't been able to find a correlation between layer count and stutter consistency. [And this isn't at all a surprise, but that bottleneck is explained later.]

Then it also feels like the code gets "stuck" in a loop when the program locks up for a few seconds for no apparent reason, other then doing one of the things that triggers the stutter, but it can be a single pixel brush taking a single stroke and the program nearly kills itself at times.... (The stutter is likely created due to this, but just jumping out from the loop within a "reasonable" time.) [This I still haven't figured why it happens, but the fix bellow seems to fix it.]

Though, I likely am not giving Gimp a good work environment, considering all the other background stuff that I likely should close. But that wasn't a problem with gimp 2.8.16 (And I have even closed most of the background programs to see if it helps, and no noticeable performance difference...)

I even tried using hardware acceleration using the OpenCL option, but no difference.

[Fix! To most of the stuttering]
I then tried lowering the number of threads that gimp will spread its workload over for compatible processes. This greatly reduced the amount of stutter. From constant, to unnoticeable. (Option is above hardware acceleration in the system Resources tab.)

I would "guess" that gimp is rather inefficient or rough in how it manages parallel execution across multiple threads. (Maybe gimp forces "small" tasks into more threads than needed? (I am not going to go into how the size of a dataset and multiprocess overhead works in depth, but to sum it up. If it takes X time to do our task, and Y time to mange each thread and we have N threads that we wish to run it on, then the time to process the total of X is equal to X/N+Y×N and this total time should preferably be within a reasonable amount of time, but if we make N very large, then Y×N is eventually going to grow larger then X/N and our resulting performance can end up far worse then X/1 (in other words running a single thread.) and working with a brush size of only a few pixels makes X fairly small. (The management process of multi threaded execution should generally have some process checking the size of the dataset needing processing, yes this will make Y a little bit bigger, but that doesn't add much if we talk about large datasets, and for small datasets we aren't wasting time and processing power managing an unreasonable amount of threads.)))

in Edit and input devices. I am only getting core pointer where as Tablet and tablet pressure are missing?

note.body:
This issue is something I experience as well.

If one opens the program using the "core pointer" ie the mouse, then Gimp will not realize that there also is a nice shiny drawing tablet connected to the system. (it will work as a mouse, and pressure sensitivity, and orientation (rotation, angle, and what side of the pen one uses) will not work.)

If one opens the program with the drawing tablet, then it happily uses the drawing tablet's fancy features.

This is the case in Gimp 2.8.16 and 2.10.4 (on Windows 8.1 in my case)

As a "quick fix", just open the program with the pen, and never with the mouse. (until the bug is sorted out.)

events.target_title: Smooth stroke seems almost pointless at current

note.body:
So I did the same semi circle test again in Gimp 2.10.10, though at three different speeds.

![Smooth_stroke_gimp_2.10.10](/uploads/918c7092247f59be801a6208b66b9d34/Smooth_stroke_gimp_2.10.10.png)

I can not see any improvement in the fast stroke. (More weight would be needed to smooth it out more. Since it does still have a clear wobble to it.) The slowest stroke has more clear improvements, the jaggedness of the hand drawn line is gone, but the smoothed line still has a clear wobble in it.

But I still would say that the problem is not fixed. Since it can obviously still get far smoother in all three cases.

In the end, the weight setting should probably not be "arbitrarily" limited to a max of 1000.
The slider can max out at 1000, like the brush size slider, but going beyond for those times when one needs/desires, would be a nice addition. (just like the brush size slider.)

(Advice I have gotten from fellow artists is to simply make faster strokes, but that isn't always possible when dealing with more swirly details. Switching to vectors is also a solution, but still not always applicable.)

events.target_title: Text entry is broken if the current keyboard layout includes certain dead keys

note.body:
Hi,

I think it happens everywhere (I've definitely noticed it in the file picker, and also while renaming layers). I think your suspicion of it being a GTK+ issue is correct. Gimp 2.8 and Inkscape are both broken as well, but in a more subtle way, there those specific AltGr + letter combinations just produce the letter in question.

Is it still supported: The tool itself: probably not anymore. But using keyboard layouts is certainly still supported. That is bread and butter stuff like using an AZERTY instead of a QWERTY layout.

It is reasonably common to use the AltGr + (letter) to produce more symbols, eg. some layouts produce '€' with AltGr + E. Binding dead keys to such combinations is a bit more unusual, but I think it is also still supported.

I wouldn't mind too much if those specific dead keys don't work, but just typing the plain letter definitely should work.

events.target_title: Text entry is broken if the current keyboard layout includes certain dead keys

note.body:
OK, I think it was me doing something silly. The specific mapping on the G key looked like this:

 - normal: **g**
 - Shift: **G**
 - AltGr: **g** (dead key).

So lower case g shows up twice in there, which is probably not a good thing.

The other thing is the combinations with subsequent key presses:

 - ...
 - **f** → φ
 - **g** → γ
 - **h** → η
 - **i** → ι
 - ...

Here as well, we have the same character g in that list. I don't know if that is a common thing to have.

I had not seen any problems in other applications before. But I can easily use a different character for the dead key. GIMP and others then work as expected.

events.target_title: Text entry is broken if the current keyboard layout includes certain dead keys

note.body:
I noticed it still doesn’t 100% work: to make sure there aren’t any duplicates I just put the combining accents (U+0300 COMBINING GRAVE ACCENT, etc) on the layout as dead keys. This works in other applications but GIMP treats them as normal keys.

So yes there are a few unusual cases which work in most applications but not in GTK+. But as long as the standard layouts shipped with Windows work I don’t think this will affect many people.

This is what I’m using now:
Source: https://github.com/roelandschoukens/QUERTY-AltGr-compose
Installer: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1wM__jZ24pHW6SV8gIb7XSuRNUXDV4a2E

Make the touchpad gestures fluent (switching desktops, overview) (something like macOS and Windows on precision touchpads)
Make the touchpad gestures fluent (switching desktops, overview) (something like macOS and Windows on precision touchpads)

note.body:
Well, there are two problems solved through this solution...
1. Touchpad gestures are there to quickly (and in a more modern sense) do stuff! With gestures I can quickly switch desktops rather than moving my hands back to the keyboard and doing complex shortcuts. Beginners especially love gestures compared to keyboard shortcuts!
2. Fluent gestures are more pleasing to the eye, as compared to the current implementation, fluent ones could solve the inherent disconnect between the user, and the gesture that takes place. Take an example of scrolling. As you perform the scroll motion with your fingers, the document on the screen slides down/up. Similarly, if the shell would switch between desktops during the 4 finger slides, or show the switch from the apps to the overview during the pinch gesture *as it happens*, that would make a much better design from a design perspective. 
(also: currently you perform the entire gesture, and *then* it switches desktops. I guess removing that delay and making the action occur straight, during the gesture would also partially solve the issue of user disconnect between what happens and what the user wants to happen, but I would say following what macOS and even Windows with precision touchpads would be better)

events.target_title: xmlInitGlobals() is not thread-safe

note.body:
I agree there is a race in the initialization of xmlThrDefMutex, but the problem is
that setting up the once variable like you did will simply not compile on Linux:

  CCLD     xmllint
/usr/bin/ld: ./.libs/libxml2.a(globals.o): undefined reference to symbol 'pthread_once@@GLIBC_2.2.5'
//usr/lib64/libpthread.so.0: error adding symbols: DSO missing from command line
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
make[2]: *** [Makefile:1120: xmllint] Error 1

  the reason is that when linking code which is single-threaded like xmllint we do not
need to link with -lpthread , have access to a faster memory allocator and avoid all that
complexity altogether at runtime. But it makes the code more complex.
  You will need to do that initialization of the mutex in threads.c where all the
libpthread entry points are defined as weak references.

  There are other pthread_once_t variables there being used that's really where all the
thread code should reside and then add the init function as __xmlInitGlobalsOnce() in libxml.h
so that it's shared between modules but not part of the API.

  thanks !

Daniel

events.target_title: xmlInitGlobals() is not thread-safe

note.body:
Sorry you have hit one of the weirdest parts of libxml2 code :-)

Daniel

events.target_title: WIP: Improve code generation for closure ref counting

note.body:
Indeed! The original patch (submitted in bugzilla) doesn't use `gint16`. But that approach wasn't acceptable due to a change of userspace ABI that it requires.

The use of `gint16` is necessitated due to the layout of `GClosure` which uses a 15-bit bitfield to store the reference count (+1 unused bit which we should probably subsume into the ref_count but I wasn't sure about the ABI implications of that).

The patch is trying to address poor code generation arising from the way closure ref counting is implemented and it's effect on performance on certain arm64 systems.

The original issue notes in bugzilla[0] has more background motivating the change.

[0] https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=791706

events.target_title: WIP: Improve code generation for closure ref counting

note.body:
I'm OK to move the 16-bit atomic ops to gclosure.c, but it makes the code harder to maintain, IMHO.

Presumably, the reason the current set of atomics are centralised is to make it easy to make changes to the atomics code. It also eases porting the library to newer targets. By localising some infrequently used operations, it is now easy to miss it when library wide atomics update is needed. And, it doesn't take away from the requirement for support on multiple platforms. 

The current shape of the patch is due to feedback from Philip. Let's give him a chance to comment on the code. I can update the patch once there's consensus.

push_data.commit_title: gclosure: Optimise g_closure_[ref|unref]()

events.target_title: WIP: Improve code generation for closure ref counting

note.body:
I belatedly realised that I'd missed updating parts that exposed the 16bit atomic operations. Fixing this has made all the platform builds pass.

@pwithnall Can you have a look at this series as a solution for #1316 when you get a chance. There's also the point raised by @nirbheek about exposing the 16-bit atomics as a public API.

note.body:
> gnome-terminal, if configured properly (that is, the shell sources `vte.sh`), opens new tabs or windows using the Ctrl+Shift+T/N shortcuts in the working directory of the active terminal. Isn't that mostly what you're looking for?

No, that's a different use case. This is about opening a new window using a keyboard shortcut.

In tiling managers, like i3, users generally prefer to have the WM manage windows, as opposed to using application-specific mechanisms, like tabs.

Let's go over an example: you log in, open a single terminal window, let's say you want to work on some source code, so you go to the directory with your sources and open a file using vim. Then you realize you need to do something else in a shell, but you don't want to quit vim, or put it in the background, so you hit mod+enter (default in i3) to open a new terminal window (this way you also get to see both the source file in one terminal and the new shell in the new terminal at the same time). The CWD you most likely want to be in, in the new terminal is the same one you were working in in the old terminal with vim open. In this case you can't rely on application-specific mechanisms - that's the problem `lastcwd` is trying to solve.

> WINDOWID was removed for three reasons I believe. One is that it's specific to the X Window system, and is unavailable under Wayland.

That's fine. I don't think it would be a problem if you only set it in X. After all it would only be useful/meaningful in X.

But if you think it needs to always be present, or always missing, you could set it to `0` in Wayland.

> The second is that it's not maintainable during drag-and-drop of tabs (even though that feature is temporarily disabled due to problems in GTK+).

xfce4-terminal and mate-terminal have drag and drop functionality and do set WINDOWID. The variable remains unchanged when you drag the tab to another window. It simply means "that's the window this shell was started in".

> The third is that this variable is purely used for ugly and broken hacks, such as displaying (mispositioned) overlay images or such.

There is software out there that relies on this variable and not all of it is bad.

In any case though, the WINDOWID variable itself is neither ugly, nor broken, nor a hack. It's present in all major terminal emulators and provides useful information. I don't see a downside to re-introducing it.

> Thinking of which, even if we resurrected this variable, your script wouldn't be able to distinguish between tabs of the same window, would it?

With one tab per window, it would work. With multiple tabs, it would not, at least not without some changes (it currently looks for the foreground descendant - with multiple tabs, there are multiple hits, so an additional condition would have to be introduced to pick the right process).

For users of tiling managers and/or tmux, that's not really an issue though. Those users tend not to use tabs, because both their WM and tmux are more convenient/powerful at managing windows.

> What's the use case where externally getting the currently focused gnome-terminal window's properties is really that relevant? Wouldn't for example the latest propmt displayed be good enough for you? In your shell prompt you could easily place the working directory somewhere in the filesystem, and then `lastcwd` could simply be a `cat`. This would even work with multiple tabs in a window.

The prompt approach has multiple downsides:
* It's unnecessarily stateful and subject to race conditions and failure scenarios (no disk space, exceeded quotas, no permissions, read-only mounts, etc.)
* It requires additional code to be executed every time you do something in a shell, to no benefit 99% of the time
* It requires unnecessary writes to disk (though you could use /dev/shm, or some such, at the cost of portability)
* Requires the user to mess with their shell profile (lastcwd does not require that)
* It's inaccurate
  * It requires a new prompt to be displayed, so it requires at least hitting enter in that shell to work - just focusing the window this shell is running in is not enough
  * The current approach works with all shells and any other programs running in them - I can start a terminal with my default zsh, then open bash to test compatibility of some code, change the cwd in bash and everything still works, with arbitrary nesting levels

To sum up - all I'm asking is for gnome-terminal to do what pretty much every other terminal emulator is doing. At best, it makes other software work, at worst it does no harm.

events.target_title: WINDOWID variable not being set makes it impossible to figure out last active/focused shell

note.body:
> > Let's go over an example: [...] - that's the problem lastcwd is trying to solve.
>
> And that's exactly what gnome-terminal's Ctrl+Shift+N (or whatever shortcut you pick) does :)

Well, not quite. lastcwd does not open terminals - it just prints the path. You can use it with anything - file managers, media players, any sort of widgets. I could have another shortcut to launch thunar in the same CWD as my focused terminal.

gnome-terminal is the "source", but not necessarily the "destination" ;]

> > xfce4-terminal and mate-terminal have drag and drop functionality and do set WINDOWID. The variable remains unchanged when you drag the tab to another window. It simply means "that's the window this shell was started in".
>
> Which meaning is utterly useless.

You mean you have no use for it ?;]

> I'd rather say that after a DND, this variable doesn't mean anything. Its current behavior is obviously not the design anyone could have ever intended, it's an inevitable limitation (read: bug).

I'm not saying WINDOWID should be re-introduced because of its elegance. I'm just trying to make do with what I have at my disposal and WINDOWID has been the missing piece for me in most other terminal emulators.

Should there be a better way ? Sure. But to be useful to users like myself, it has to apply across the board. I can't handle every terminal emulator specially. I could never cover all of them and my code would multiply in size and bugs. That's why I'm asking for the re-introduction of WINDOWID - because that's the only realistic way of getting something users can use in pretty much every terminal emulator.

> > With one tab per window, it would work. With multiple tabs, it would not, at least not without some changes (it currently looks for the foreground descendant - with multiple tabs, there are multiple hits, so an additional condition would have to be introduced to pick the right process).
>
> I don't see how you could add that additional condition (without some explicit help from gnome-terminal).

I haven't thought about it in depth. It probably would require asking gnome-terminal somehow.

> > For users of tiling managers and/or tmux, that's not really an issue though. Those users tend not to use tabs, because both their WM and tmux are more convenient/powerful at managing windows.
>
> I'm not super keen on reintroducing a broken feature that works correctly under a certain set of conditions.

I understand your reasoning. You want a clean solution, but we can't make all terminal emulators implement something new any time soon. What we can do right away though, is follow existing conventions until something better gets widely implemented.

> > The prompt approach has multiple downsides:
> > 
> >- It's unnecessarily stateful and subject to race conditions and failure scenarios (no disk space, exceeded quotas, no permissions, read-only mounts, etc.)
> 
> The race can easily be avoided, since file move operations are atomic (but the chance of the prompt getting displayed at the same time in two tabs is pretty negligible to begin with).

If I tail some files in multiple terminal windows and run `killall tail', that will cause multiple prompts to be reevaluated at more or less the same time. Whichever shell wins the race, gets to claim it was the last active one. The result would have nothing to do with window focus.

But you don't even need a race to make the results incorrect - just open one terminal and change focus to another terminal with a different CWD.

> Other failure conditions aren't a concern: if they occur then VTE and gnome-terminal (and their underlying infrastructure) probably fail to perform their basic duties and you're likely to hit other bigger problems in the system; not opening the new terminal in the desired directory will be the least of your worries.

Meh, I run out of disk space in /home on a regular basis. Doesn't mean I have to start opening terminals in the wrong CWD ;]

And permissions issues in $HOME are not that rare. All it takes is to mount $HOME in a container running as root. All of a sudden you have files owned by root in your home directory.

Sure, these may not be common cases, but the inaccuracy of the prompt-based approach was the main reason I gave up on it, these are just additional reasons.

> > [...] at the cost of portability
>
> I'm not convinced your shell script is portable :)

I haven't tested it on other systems, but in theory it should work on any *nix with bash, coreutils, grep, procps-ng and xorg-xprop installed (running X of course). I guess the most likely thing that could cause trouble is ps.

> > To sum up - all I'm asking is for gnome-terminal to do what pretty much every other terminal emulator is doing. At best, it makes other software work, at worst it does no harm.
>
> IMHO reporting a wrong value, performing operations on the wrong window, can potentially mislead the user and hence cause minor harm. (And even though DND is disabled now, I wouldn't want to make these two things depend on each other. I wouldn't want to delay re-enabling DND due to WINDOWID then becoming broken, nor re-introduce WINDOWID now and re-ditch as soon as DND is fixed.)

But it's not a choice between potentially misleading some software, or not.

It's a choice between having that software work like in other terminal emulators, or not work, in some cases partially, and in some cases at all.

> The removal of this variable was sneaked in to commit 0820b385, with a comment added at https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-terminal/blob/3.28.2/src/terminal-screen.c#L1213. I cannot comment on the Gdk and re-realized bits, I don't have enough knowledge to exactly understand the problems they refer to.
>
> Another interesting thought is at an irrelevant bug https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=747800#c2 saying "gnome-terminal is GNOME's terminal application". Being a GNOME Terminal developer it always makes me happy to hear if someone is using this piece of software, but perhaps another VTE-based terminal emulator (hence providing the exact same actual terminal emulation, just a different UI, with no tabs etc.) would be a better fit for tiling window managers??

Sure. But I wanted lastcwd to work with any terminal. And people do use gnome-terminal with various WMs.

> Peeking under /proc (as pwdx does in your script) to get the directory was replaced in gnome-terminal 3.8 (5 years ago) with shells (and perhaps other apps) explicitly telling the directory to gnome-terminal using the OSC 7 escape sequence. This new method has several advantages over the old one, including the ability of apps (e.g. file managers) updating the value, remembering symlink components, being platform independent, having a chance of being terminal emulator independent etc. Going back to the old approach, even if in your script, would be IMHO unfortunate.

Well, strictly speaking, peeking under /proc was replaced with the hope that other software will use those sequences ;]

That doesn't seem to be the case for dash (default shell in Debian), ksh (default in OpenBSD), or tcsh (default in FreeBSD). Unless I'm doing something wrong while testing this.

> What I'm currently thinking about (and would love to hear @chpe's opinion) is some means of querying gnome-terminal-server. E.g. a command `gnome-terminal --tell-me-the-cwd-of-the-last-focused-tab`. Would this be okay for you?

This would break with tmux and some shells. I'd rather get the PID of the shell in the active tab, so I can figure out the CWD myself.

> Alternatively, gnome-terminal could maybe place the last active tab's working directory in the window's X properties. That would still be specific to X11, but wouldn't suffer from the DND problem and would use the OSC 7 value rather than digging in /proc. (Not sure if there's a GTK+ method for this, though. Direct X11 dependency is a no-go.)

An X property would be fine.

Anyhow, thanks for the response ;]

So all that the wanted 'global shortcut' needs to do send a dbus call to g-t-server ('gdbus call ....') to activate that action with the appropriate parameters.

note.body:
> > I could have another shortcut to launch thunar in the same CWD as my focused terminal.
> 
> Can you have a shortcut that launches a terminal in the same CWD as opened in thunar? If so, how do you do it technically? Or is this only supposed to work in one direction, from terminals, but not from other apps?

The idea was to use terminal descendants as sources, because other processes usually have a CWD that's not of practical use. But lastcwd will still do it's thing with any source. So if you do `cd ~/Music && some-media-player`, lastcwd will print "$HOME/Music" when the media player window is the source, which can be useful, but usually not so much.

The state in file managers/media players is not CWD, but I get the idea, it would be nice to return the path the user navigated to in thunar, but I don't know of a generally applicable way to extract that information. I suppose I could go down the path of special handling for popular applications. I don't want to, but it would be neat to have the functionality...

> Many of our users want tabs support. Few of our users want WINDOWID. The two features cannot work correctly together, they are incompatible. Well, they can work correctly as long as each user solely uses one or the other, but not both. Adding both features and asking users not to use both at the same time is IMO not how software should be built. Sometimes compromises have to be made, and we made one here.

Do many users really use tabs ? I'm not saying that's not true, it's just surprising. Terminal tabs are pretty primitive compared to WM/multiplexer-handled windows. And killing the terminal kills all its children, which is not an issue if you're using a multiplexer like tmux, instead of tabs...

> > I can't handle every terminal emulator specially. [...] It probably would require asking gnome-terminal somehow.
>
> Bummer! :)

Yep. I knew going in, that I'll have to handle terminal multiplexers specially, but I was really hoping that would not be necessary with terminal emulators ;/

> > If I tail some files in multiple terminal windows and run `killall tail', that will cause multiple prompts to be reevaluated at more or less the same time. Whichever shell wins the race, gets to claim it was the last active one.
>
> This is not what "race condition" means.

The race condition is in writing the file, but `killall tail' starts the qualifying round - decides who will participate in the main event ;] So while it's not a "race condition", the "race" metaphor seems to apply.

> > That doesn't seem to be the case for dash (default shell in Debian), ksh (default in OpenBSD), or tcsh (default in FreeBSD). Unless I'm doing something wrong while testing this.
>
> You should ask your distributions/vendors to configure these to emit OSC 7. As far as I recall, OSC 7 originates from macOS's Terminal.app, and was adapted by at least iTerm2, Konsole and of course GNOME Terminal (probably a few more VTE-based terminal emulators too). It's not some rare odd thingie.

Don't get me wrong, it's a good fight you're asking me to join, but it's not my fight ;]

If I was a terminal developer, I'd be on the same side of this argument as you. It's better to have a clean solution and you can afford to wait for it indefinitely, because why not ?

But I'm a user and I want to solve a specific problem in a short time frame.

> > This would break with tmux and some shells.
>
> Then let's add OSC 7 support to tmux too!

That would be one way to do it. 

Another one would be for gnome-terminal to become tmux-aware - use the api provided by tmux to figure out the CWD, like lastcwd does. But of course, you'd rather not implement special handling for some software running in gnome-terminal. That's the same boat I'm in ;]

> Let's get away from X, if possible. If you insist on figuring out the cwd yourself, rather than relying on OSC 7,

I have to. Otherwise lastcwd won't work with some shells and tmux.

> and you wish to have the chlid process's PID, how about a `gnome-terminal --give-me-the-pid-of-the-child-process-in-the-last-focused-tab`? Or, rather, a more generic `gnome-terminal --dump-the-state-of-windows-and-tabs` which would print in some easily parseable format

Yeah, that would make sense.

> (xml? json? yaml? ad-hoc?)

XML and JSON seem a bit excessive. How about just key-value pairs separated by a character like `=` ? One per line ? Easy to parse without special libraries. Would make it more accessible in languages like bash.

> what windows it has, what tabs it has in them, what their size, title, cwd, child pid etc. are, what the value of GNOME_TERMINAL_{SCREEN,SERVICE} is in them, and mark somehow the currently focused (if any), the last focused, etc...?

Sounds good.

note.body:
JSON/YAML:
* Extensible
* Convenient parsing in many languages (may require new dependencies), not doable in shell scripts without new dependencies

INI:
* Less extensible (can't nest sections)
* Convenient parsing in many languages (may require new dependencies), doable in shell scripts (with, or without new dependencies)

KEY/VALUE:
* Extensible
* Mixed convenience in parsing, no new dependencies required

What sort of languages are most likely to be used with this feature ? How complex can the structure get long-term ?

events.target_title: WINDOWID variable not being set makes it impossible to figure out last active/focused shell

note.body:
> I'm not sure why a yaml is harder to parse in shell scripts than ini files are. (I might need to try :))

JSON/YAML have arbitrary nesting. INI only has one level.

So with INI you just need to remember the current section and you parse key/value pairs.
You can store the results for the whole file in a simple one-dimensional associative array.

With JSON/YAML things get considerably more complicated with more nesting levels. The parsing is no longer just a loop over key/value pairs, there is more state to remember and storage requires nested dictionaries, which can be simulated in bash, but it all gets more awkward and more complicated.

The above of course applies to parsing the input without using dedicated tools/libraries. If you use `jq` from bash, it's simple, but you've added a dependency to your script. Possibly one that didn't require the user to install anything new before.

(I'm not covering all the special notations, (un)quoting, etc. you need to handle in JSON/YAML, to have a proper parser)

> Key/value, as you think of it, is like just one section of an ini file, am I correct? It could go something like

Key/value is just that - `key=value` - one per line, no sections, no state to remember.

You can represent arbitrarily nested structures this way, by embedding the names of nested sections in the key names. This has mixed consequences - you can no longer use nice libraries/tools, so if you want to consume the whole structure, it becomes more tedious, but if you only care about a single value, you can trivially grep for the right key.

INI:
```
[foo]
a=1
b_c=2

[bar]
a=3
b_c=4
```

Key/value:
```
foo__a=1
foo__b_c=2
bar__a=3
bar__b_c=4
```

note.body:
> I wasn't clear, sorry. I meant whether it's easier to parse that one particular INI, or that one particular YAML format gnome-terminal would produce (without writing a generic parser). That particular YAML could  be parsed by looking at prefixes like "- - " and such.

The only reliable way of parsing JSON/YAML is to use a JSON/YAML parser.

Implementing something that only handles one nesting level and doesn't cover many parts of the format, as it is specified, seems like a bad idea.

I mean, if you just want to grab one value, a grep/cut hack might do, but it would certainly feel wrong.

> Another approach we could take is to emit something that you could just `eval` in `bash`, and would define the right variables (associative arrays, etc.) :-)

Eval is evil.

But if you want, the key/value format constitutes valid code in virtually every shell (modulo special characters).

PS. There's also the option of just using X properties in X and whatever the equivalent is in Wayland. Seems like a natural choice...

events.target_title: hiding scrollbars
hiding scrollbars

note.body:
I've looked into this, and I hereby request you change this ticket to a feature request.  
I'll explain why below.

*In the past...*  
GTK+ had Ubuntu overlay scrollbars. There were various ways to disable them, including `export LIBOVERLAY_SCROLLBAR=0`, apt removing various (lib)overlay-scrollbar* packages, via programs (gsettings, gconf-editor, gnome-tweaks, etc) and via various GUIs provided by window managers.

*Noaways...*  
The toolkit itself no longer offers an overlay scrollbar setting, to prevent such a blanket toolkit toggle from breaking applications that haven't been tested with both combinations. The overlay nature of the scrollbars is now part of the toolkit. To allow application developers to decide what their applications should look like, the toolkit provides a mechanism to opt-out or add a setting for users.

The function [gtk_scrolled_window_set_overlay_scrolling()](https://developer.gnome.org/gtk3/stable/GtkScrolledWindow.html#gtk-scrolled-window-set-overlay-scrolling) can be used to enable/disable overlay scrolling. Application developers can optionally use [GSettings](https://blog.gtk.org/2017/05/01/first-steps-with-gsettings/) to have a user setting bound to the property.

events.target_title: Infinite loop while connecting to RDP
Super+number key combos can't be overriden in GNOME 3.32

note.body:
Hi. 

These defaults are counterintuitive and they're broke my UX. I'm using super+<n> for switching workspaces, and I'm constantly having trouble with opening unwanted apps (I have 4 workspaces, but I'm accidentally hitting 5 key and so on).  

I searched for keybindings in settings, but they're not exposed there. I thought that Dash-to-dock is responsible for them, but no - it's shortcuts are disabled. Now I've found this issue and see the workaround - a for loop in the terminal. Good luck for a Mr. Joe Average...

It's not consistent to have workspaces shortcuts from super-<1-4>, then apps shortcuts starting from 5. There should be at least one small switch to disable apps keybindings. And they should be disabled by default, because user cannot see them in Keyboard Shortcuts settings.

events.target_title: Support color fonts in gucharmap
Support color fonts in gucharmap

note.body: I don't know what "text presentation" of a glyph means. A glyph is an outline, and for color fonts, there is auxiliary color information, attached to various paths of glyph. Why would that not be within the scope of gucharmap, which is a generic unicode viewer? Why is color information less important than shape? Further, the fact that gucharmap is already showing these glyphs in gray level (not binary black white) shows that it is just a question of rendering the glyphs in an RGB surface instead of the current gray level surface.

events.target_title: Support color fonts in gucharmap

note.body: Thanks! I wasn't familiar with that term. I would still argue that showing the glyphs in the chosen font, but in gray level, is not fulfilling the specification of a text presentation. You would need a special font for that.

events.target_title: Video Wallpapers for Desktop and Lockscreen

note.body:
@fmuellner That's cool!

I don't know enough programming (I'm a designer learning to develop) to really contribute so I don't want to be entitled or anything of that sort. In my view though, the question of "in scope" is sort of a tricky one with animated wallpapers, because fundamentally, wallpapers either video or color changing etc are never really necessary for an OS. They're purely aesthetic. So if the question is "do people want video backgrounds?" I would say yes, I think some do. But how many people do, or if that should be a priority of developers, I don't really know. 

I can also point to an example of third party application that does provide this functionality. Komorebi provides this functionality. It was not working on Ubuntu until yesterday when I checked in with the developer and alerted them to the pull requests in their repo. https://github.com/iabem97/komorebi

Komorebi overlies Gnome's background, and disables the native desktop right click menu. I actually like the Komorebi right click menu's visuals a bit more but it does lack some features of the normal context menu and the application itself is not particularly native looking and has some integrations with the rest of the desktop environment. 

Also it only does the background and it can not control the lock screen which is also a feature I think can be used for aesthetic purposes quite well. 

I also know that adding this feature to Gnome Shell or to Tweaks can open the door to a lot of bad dumb ugly interfaces, but I think there are some prime examples of subtle and interesting uses of motion on Windows ricing customization forums that are worth seeing. 

I also see you added a needs design label. I'm a designer! I could help. What kind of thing would I need to do to help with that process?

The design I have in mind is pretty minimal, it's really just adding a second dialog box to the existing background and lock screen sections which allows one to specific image or video. That's how it's handled in the KDE mod I mentioned.

note.body:
The behavior I saw is very similar to #1885, but I'm skeptical that #1198 is the same issue. I experienced behavior like #1198 very often in 2.8; almost every time I exported a JPEG I'd need to click on a different GIMP window and then back on the dialog to give it focus. But the options problem seems different in two ways. First, I did a lot of clicking outside and inside and it made no difference. Second, the options window did respond to clicks on the configure triangle in the upper right, or the preset icons at the bottom, so it didn't seem to be a focus problem.

(I don't mean to argue with you about whether #1198 is the same or not, but just want to provide information that might be helpful.)

An issue with non-utf locale and g_format_size_full
An issue with non-utf locale and g_format_size_full

note.body:
Hi, I don't know. I use utf8. It was just an example.

Originally, I got a report some time ago from a french person: https://github.com/megous/megatools/issues/270

I suppose it's rare. I got just a single bugreport in 5 years. There may be other locales where it's more frequent to use other encodings than utf8. I really don't have knowledge in this area though. Perhaps some asian countries?

It's probably not that hard to work around this in this specific case from my app's perspective. I'll just not use g_format_size_full and do some hackery on my own with locale conversion, or whatever.

At least, it should perhaps be docummented in g_*_printf or the documentation page about charsets/locales, that there may be issues if people use formatting specifiers that may output non-ascii characters.

I guess fixing printf would be a headache, and not worh it. Fixing just g_format_size_full to return utf8 strings might be easier, but perhaps still not worth it. It's ultimately up to you.

events.target_title: An issue with non-utf locale and g_format_size_full

note.body:
> I suspect the solution will be to modify our printf wrapper to transcode to UTF-8 if running in a non-UTF-8 locale.

That might prove harder than it sounds. Consider a format string printf("kůň %'.1f", ...). Output will be mixed utf-8 and whatever locale encoding is. So you can't just transcode the output. You can first transcode format string to a locale encoding and then back after the printf does its job. But you've just added two transcodings for all g_*_printf calls you have. I guess you can first scan the format string for occurance of format sctrings that may produce non-ascii output by themselves and skip all this if locale is utf8 encoded.

events.target_title: An issue with non-utf locale and g_format_size_full

note.body:
> You can first transcode format string to a locale encoding and then back after the printf does its job.

Actually you can't even do that. Because if there's %s somewhere in there, it will still introduce an utf-8 encoded string into the mix.

And that's on top of the protability problems you've just mentioned.

It also appears to be the same bug listed here.:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/issues/789

I can confirm that closing xnviewmp while copying a selection from a larg*ish* image does prevent the crash. Copy is also noticeably quicker when xnviewmp is not open. With xnview open, the copy operation in gimp brings up the busy cursor for a few seconds.

I followed the post referenced above and removed the .config/GIMP folder and couldn't get gimp to fail. I then started adding back my resources and config files in chunks until everything is as it was, but I can't get it to fail again. note.body:
Assuming the following contents in a ZFS filesystem (called `test-trash`) mounted in `$HOME`:

```
ubuntu@build-gnome:~/test-trash$ ls -la
total 3
drwxr-xr-x  3 ubuntu lxd     4 Dec  4 14:27 ./
drwxr-xr-x 12 ubuntu ubuntu 18 Dec  4 14:25 ../
drwxr-xr-x  2 ubuntu lxd     3 Dec  4 13:51 dir1/
-rw-r--r--  1 ubuntu lxd     6 Dec  4 13:51 file1.txt
```

Trying to trash a file with system `gio` fails as follows:
```
$ /usr/bin/gio trash file1.txt
gio: file:///home/ubuntu/test-trash/file1.txt: Trashing on system internal mounts is not supported 
```

Using the self-built `gio` it works as expected (again creating `.Trash-1000/` and moving files there):
```
ubuntu@build-gnome:~/test-trash$ gio trash file1.txt
ubuntu@build-gnome:~/test-trash$ ls -la .Trash-1000/**
.Trash-1000/files:
total 2
drwx------ 2 ubuntu ubuntu 3 Dec  4 14:51 .
drwx------ 4 ubuntu ubuntu 4 Dec  4 14:51 ..
-rw-r--r-- 1 ubuntu lxd    6 Dec  4 13:51 file1.txt

.Trash-1000/info:
total 2
drwx------ 2 ubuntu ubuntu  3 Dec  4 14:51 .
drwx------ 4 ubuntu ubuntu  4 Dec  4 14:51 ..
-rw-r--r-- 1 ubuntu ubuntu 61 Dec  4 14:51 file1.txt.trashinfo
```

note.body:
@oholy If I understand you correctly, you're right that you can't explore/access the ZFS dataset tree (i.e what you see with `zfs list`) solely though the FS (i.e. you need to use the `zfs` CLI or use native APIs). :neutral_face:

ZFS will report the maximum space that a dataset can grow to (roughly `has quota ? quota : max(used space, reserved space) + pool wide free space`) as its "available" space (even if it's shared with other datasets in the pool). So if one dataset grows the "available" space for all datasets in the pool shrinks. I admit it's a little unintuitive if you're only used to fixed-size volumes. :sweat\_smile:

This may be fixed in a version of Software that hasn't made it to me. I am running 3.28.2 under Fedora 28.  I *HAVE* taken a big ole system update a few days ago after installing.  But when I opened Software and chose the Update tab to see if there were updates, there was the happy check mark with "Up to Date"

I clicked on the arrow in a circle in the upper left hand corner of Software, and about five minutes later it came back saying there were indeed updates to the OS, Firefox, Evolution and others.

events.target_title: Show progress when downloading updates

note.body:
I am sad that, after all this time, there is still no progress indication of any sort.  When I run Software 3.28.2 under Fedora 28, which appears to be quite recent, all I see is the spinning indicator. The wording is so similar, I never even notice the transitions between Checking for updates and Downloading updates. I think we need:
1. A progress bar that indicates how far along we are in the checking process.
2. When the checking process is done, the list of software to be updated should be posted.
3. The list of software to update should give a download/install progress bar for each and every line item.

To the point raised earlier about the OS taking a disproportionate amount of the download/update time: So be it.  That line item should be shown.

A possibly instructive approach to this display would be the Apple App Store that gives exactly these progress indications, and also gives the option to proceed or not with each line item.

note.body:
My use case is unrelated to Type=Link desktop files, but your blog post says to write here for .desktop use cases so I hope this is the right place.

For work I keep multiple Chromium browser profiles on removable media, so that I have access to them regardless of which PC I happen to be working on at the time. In order to make it easy to open these profiles, since they are not stored in my user's Chromium config directory, I have added a couple of .desktop files to the root of my removable drive that execute chromium and load the appropriate profile (e.g. `Exec=/usr/bin/chromium-browser --user-data-dir=chromium-test/profiles --disk-cache-dir="chromium-test/cache"`). For now I will simply replace the .desktop file with a shell script that launches the command, but I prefer having the ability to use a launcher format without the prompt to "open or execute text file". I know I can turn that off and execute by default, but I like the ability to choose when writing shell scripts - I don't need it for a pure launcher though.

events.target_title: Allow users to set Monday to be first day of week in Calendar

note.body:
The collective term for Saturday and Sunday is "the weekEND". Hence the only logical choice for first day of the week is Monday. Yes yes, I realize that the first day of the week on the calendar is arbitrary, but come on.. At the very least users should have a choice to override the regional default if that makes no sense.

BTW Greg, you can edit /etc/locale.conf to add LC_TIME="en_GB.UTF-8" (or edit the existing entry, if your system includes LC_TIME="en_US.UTF-8"). It seems to be working fine so far and hasn't been affected by any updates. (I found this solution here https://askubuntu.com/questions/6016/how-to-set-monday-as-the-first-day-of-the-week-in-gnome-calendar-applet).

So let me rephrase and transform this as a "wishlist" bug:

it would be nice to be able to choose your location, or fallback to the timezone if location isn't available. At least, it would be nice to the user to explain somewhere in the settings that this is dependent of the location or notify this might not be accurate since location service is disabled.

note.body:
Timezone as a fallback would have worked for me, since I disabled location in privacy settings. I was actually expecting Night light to use the timezone since I had forgotten about location.

That said, it's a general thing about location, apps/settings that use it should IMO have a fallback if it's relevant (like with timezone in this case), or (non exclusive or) notify you somehow when you enable a feature that relies on location when the location service isn't available (as it would on other systems, e.g. Android). Location service could allow you to set a location to your liking, too. That would preserve enough privacy for most users (or at least for me ;) ).

events.target_title: gnome-shell freezes on notification arrival

note.body:
I ran into ugly pauses with new windows opening. I have three monitors and 3-4 second pauses opening a terminal or firefox. Running 

    journalctl -S `date '+%Y-%m-%d'`

showed that the pixel-saver extension was struggling. Disabling that solved those long jams.

note.body:
@ebassi 
Done: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/merge_requests/202


@pwithnall
This can not be absolute, it is still new kqueue() GFileMonitor backend implementation with new features.
I will not do any "improvements" to current kqueue() backend even if you pay a lot of money.

> To put it another way, this is unlikely to be accepted unless you can demonstrate that it’s an improvement over the current kqueue backend and introduces no regressions; or unless the authors of the current kqueue backend vouch for this one being an improvement. 

This is too many work for free open source project.
I do not understand why there is so hard to replace old broken code, that was broken during many years:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/commits/master/gio/kqueue
from 05 Jun, 2015 to ~ 18 May, 2018 and still works bad.
Your motivation is unclear to me.

events.target_title: New kqueue() GFileMonitor backend

note.body:
Well, I can move it to gio/kqueueng or gio/kqueue_freebsd to avoid this bureaucracy.
Is it acceptable?


>  which makes not caring about a code drop with no regression testing

Because it does not work while years, it was disabled in FreeBSD during ~half year, then it was enabled it causes apps crashes and high CPU usage. So not to have this code at all was match better then have it and use it.
So value/cost of current code is ZERO and less zero for BSD community. IMHO.

I do not test original glib last year, but I am sure that it still generates GUI freezes and high CPU usage (because use polling) on desktop.


>  wildly different code style

Lets negotiate this.
I prefer to keep kqueue_fnm style and OS API, and treat it as linkable library.
gkqueuefilemonitor.c - only wrapper, I can reformat it.


>  thrown over the wall by a single person, that much easy to not care about

BSD community not so big as linux, and BSD desktop users who can and want to debug this not so many.
GNOME community can continue ignore our problems.
Is it the position of the whole GNOME community?

events.target_title: Copying a section from a png exported from a 16-bit image crashes gimp

note.body:
As it now turns out, the Gimp crash is due of having open another image file (small jpg of ~70kb is sufficient) in another program not compiled on the same machine: 

XnView MP Linux; Version 0.90 64bits (Mar 5 2018; Libformat version 7.16):
https://download.xnview.com/XnViewMP-linux-x64.tgz

Having XnView open is not a problem; once it has a image-file loaded, the above crash becomes reproducible

The file open in The Gimp when crashing, does not need to be made with XnView, 
the file that is open in XnView does not need to be the same as the file open in The Gimp - and can be very small, a jpg or a png; 
As long as something is open in XnView, The Gimp crashes when copying something from a large file (tif, png, jpg). 

It does not matter whether XnView is run from /opt or from some other folder. I use 'sh xnview.sh' to start it; using ./XnView does not work, it asks for Qt5.9:
`
bash-4.4$ ./XnView
./XnView: /usr/lib64/libQt5Core.so.5: version 'Qt_5.9' not found (required by ./XnView)
`

Maybe there are some resources that need sharing but cannot; XnView is built in another environment than Slackware (current).

I tried again with 2 USK keys, 8 Go FAT32 and 16 Go Ext4.

- When I format them with GNOME Disks, it's OK.
- When I modify the partition size with GParted, it's OK, it begins from 0.
- When I delete the partition with GParted and then, create a new one, GParted only want to start it from 1. But in fact, it really starts from 0 because after, when I modify the partition size with GParted, it's OK, it begins from 0 :

created using GNOME Disks and when created using GParted :
